title: Episode 37 – Dr Nicola Siso, PhD, hosts “Aspen Talks Health”
subtitle: Sarah Arao Mantle of Hope- Thank You Video to the Y on Earth Community for GoFundMe Campaign Support
full_transcript:
[5.3s - 10.9s]: Welcome to the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.

[11.5s - 17.0s]: Today I have the great privilege of visiting with Dr. Nikola Siso.

[17.6s - 18.1s]: Hi Nikola.

[18.3s - 20.4s]: Hello, thank you for having me on your podcast.

[20.7s - 26.3s]: It's so great to have you on the show and it's such a funny situation here because we're

[26.3s - 30.0s]: actually in your studio setup for your show.

[30.1s - 30.6s]: That's right.

[31.3s - 36.8s]: I'm the founder of Aspen Talks Health where we discuss all sorts of health related topics,

[37.1s - 42.8s]: nutrition, exercise, diet, brain health, gut health, environmental toxins.

[43.4s - 45.5s]: So you were quite a compliment to my show today.

[45.9s - 46.1s]: Thank you.

[46.1s - 47.6s]: This is so much fun.

[47.7s - 52.5s]: We get to basically interview each other in converse situations.

[52.5s - 54.8s]: We even changed chairs for the occasion.

[54.8s - 55.3s]: Didn't we?

[55.5s - 55.6s]: Yes.

[56.1s - 61.8s]: So Dr. Nikola Siso is a PhD in holistic health and nutrition.

[63.0s - 65.7s]: She is also a certified holistic health coach.

[66.1s - 71.9s]: And as she mentioned, she's the founder of Aspen Talks Health where she interviews experts

[71.9s - 74.4s]: in every aspect of health and healing.

[74.9s - 80.7s]: And she has a master's in sustainability and environmental management from Harvard University.

[81.7s - 87.7s]: And so before we dive into a number of the topical areas where your expert related to our

[87.7s - 94.7s]: personal health, I want to ask you, Nikola, how did you get into all of this in the first place?

[95.5s - 97.7s]: Health has always been a ventious to me.

[97.9s - 103.6s]: Since I was 15 years old, I loved diving into the spirituality and the emotional components

[103.6s - 104.1s]: of health.

[104.1s - 110.7s]: And then the nutrition as well, my mother studied at the Hippocrates Health Institute 20 years

[110.7s - 111.0s]: ago.

[111.6s - 117.6s]: And so we've learned how to be on a plant-based diet healthfully because there's ways

[117.6s - 118.5s]: to do it unhealthy.

[119.4s - 123.7s]: And then I actually ended up developing type 1 diabetes despite all of that.

[124.4s - 130.1s]: And so that led me even further into understanding what are some of the root causes because it's

[130.2s - 137.1s]: not just genetic and it's certainly not just sugar, high fat diets, antibiotic use, adverse

[137.1s - 140.2s]: childhood experiences, mold exposure.

[140.6s - 147.7s]: I mean, I'm learning so much as to the causes of health decline that it's never just one

[147.7s - 148.0s]: thing.

[148.8s - 152.2s]: So the show came about just because I'm personally interested.

[153.0s - 158.4s]: And I do it anyway for joy every day is learning from experts in all these different fields.

[159.0s - 161.2s]: So why not share what I'm learning with the community?

[161.6s - 164.3s]: It's so powerful and such an incredible resource.

[164.3s - 170.4s]: I want to just mention really quickly since we're on the topic, folks can find this resource

[170.4s - 173.4s]: at aspenetalkshealth.com.

[174.3s - 180.5s]: You're also on YouTube at a channel which will make sure is in the show notes and your

[180.5s - 183.4s]: Facebook is Aspen Talks Health as well.

[184.0s - 190.8s]: So I want to make sure folks that you get to this resource and see not only the expertise

[190.8s - 197.5s]: that Dr. Ciso is bringing to the public but also that her guests on the show are bringing

[197.5s - 198.3s]: to the public as well.

[198.4s - 203.9s]: And I have to ask you because I also have this wonderful privilege of interviewing a variety

[203.9s - 204.7s]: of experts.

[205.1s - 211.7s]: What's been the most unusual or surprising insight or guest that you've had on the show?

[213.1s - 220.6s]: I would say Dr. Rudy Tanzi, he is a professor of neurology at Harvard Medical School,

[221.0s - 228.2s]: discovered the genes that cause Alzheimer's and he said that they did a whole study on how

[228.2s - 234.0s]: to prevent Alzheimer's and one of the list was being more loving.

[235.6s - 240.2s]: And I found that so beautiful because so much of our, we think so much of the health is

[240.2s - 248.0s]: just related to nutrition and environmental toxins for example which a good majority is

[248.0s - 253.4s]: but also how are we treating ourselves and how loving are we being to other people in our lives.

[254.1s - 257.5s]: It was a beautiful thing that actually prevented Alzheimer's.

[257.5s - 259.0s]: That is extraordinary.

[259.4s - 259.5s]: Yeah.

[259.6s - 260.9s]: I love hearing that.

[261.0s - 261.3s]: Thank you.

[261.4s - 266.8s]: So one of the things that strikes me you know I have the opportunity to connect with folks from

[266.8s - 267.9s]: a variety of backgrounds.

[268.5s - 272.9s]: Some who might be really faith oriented in their connection with the world.

[273.1s - 279.1s]: Some who might be science oriented, STEM oriented, others who might be focused more on economy

[279.1s - 279.8s]: and so forth.

[280.6s - 285.9s]: And one of the things I have found that a lot of my friends who focus on the science lens

[285.9s - 294.6s]: is we can often fall into the trap of seeing all this kind of reduced mechanism, mechanical

[295.2s - 299.8s]: phenomena as dictating things like health or things like sustainability and what have you

[300.6s - 304.4s]: and to have somebody from the medical community emphasizing the importance of love

[304.4s - 306.9s]: is tremendous, right?

[307.5s - 307.5s]: 

[307.8s - 308.6s]: It is beautiful.

[308.9s - 315.1s]: Of course love has been central to so much of our human wisdom and teachings over the ages

[315.1s - 316.2s]: from all different cultures.

[316.6s - 317.5s]: Yeah, it's so true.

[317.8s - 322.0s]: We just, we don't think we're conscious all the time of the inner dialogue.

[322.5s - 323.6s]: So much of it is subconscious.

[324.6s - 326.1s]: And it's ruling our lives.

[326.6s - 331.4s]: And it's attracting things into our lives and it's certainly manifesting as physical ailments

[331.4s - 334.5s]: if there are so many sabotaging beliefs in there.

[334.8s - 334.9s]: Yeah.

[335.9s - 341.8s]: So for you personally with all of the technical knowledge you have, what are some of the

[341.8s - 346.9s]: things you're doing day to day week to week to cultivate that love, whether it's self-lover,

[347.1s - 348.4s]: love directed toward others?

[349.3s - 353.8s]: One thing is certainly doing a meditation practice in the morning, having that, even if it's

[353.8s - 356.7s]: just three minutes of breathing, it's so key.

[357.0s - 358.1s]: And I just, I keep it simple.

[358.6s - 364.8s]: I count inhale one, exhale two, inhale three, exhale four, and I go to six and I start

[364.8s - 365.1s]: over.

[365.6s - 368.9s]: And the reason that's to keep it short is it keeps your mind focused on the inhale and

[368.9s - 370.6s]: it, but inhaling and exhaling.

[371.4s - 375.6s]: The other thing is to look in the mirror and say, I love you, I love you and see the parts

[375.6s - 378.8s]: that you love about yourself instead of focusing on the parts that you don't.

[379.4s - 381.3s]: That has been a big transformer for me.

[381.3s - 387.3s]: And also one of the biggest, most powerful lessons I've learned this past year was that

[387.3s - 393.3s]: every single experience and every person that comes into my life be a positive or negative

[393.3s - 395.6s]: is in direct service to my soul.

[396.9s - 400.1s]: And if I could see everything, how is this serving me?

[400.9s - 406.4s]: And even if it's negative and you're like, that person is a full in the blank and they're

[406.4s - 412.9s]: just behaving unkindly, how can I actually use this as a way to practice kindness or practice

[412.9s - 413.9s]: compassion?

[414.6s - 418.2s]: You know, who knows what they're going through or how they're erased or whatever it was?

[418.5s - 423.8s]: So seeing every single experience as an opportunity to be more loving.

[424.2s - 425.0s]: It's absolutely beautiful.

[425.1s - 425.3s]: Yeah.

[426.1s - 431.8s]: I have to mention, this reminds me of my, my mother is so good at sometimes reminding me.

[431.8s - 435.2s]: And you know, when we're doing this kind of work, when we're reaching out, sharing with the

[435.2s - 441.1s]: public, interfacing networking, scheduling, invariably we can run into some friction here and there,

[441.2s - 441.4s]: right?

[442.6s - 447.9s]: And my mother reminds me often that if somebody is coming at us with, you know, kind of cold,

[448.1s - 454.4s]: prickly feelings or whatever, that is almost certainly about something going on in their lives

[454.4s - 458.6s]: and has virtually nothing to do with me or us necessarily.

[458.8s - 458.9s]: Right.

[458.9s - 464.8s]: And to learn not to take that kind of stuff quite as personally and certainly not to then amplify

[464.8s - 466.0s]: it or redirect it, right?

[466.1s - 471.5s]: I think that's one of the things that can often happen when we're having these negative experiences.

[471.8s - 477.8s]: Yeah, there's a projection of their own inner unhappiness or dissatisfaction with themselves often

[477.8s - 482.9s]: or, yeah, and you can't, to take things personally is really pointless.

[484.4s - 488.6s]: Unless it's constructive criticism from a friend and there's like something that you can

[488.6s - 489.6s]: learn from, that's different.

[489.9s - 489.9s]: Yeah.

[490.3s - 495.0s]: But if it's just a projection, then, yeah, you have to just honor the person where they are.

[495.2s - 495.6s]: Mm-hmm.

[496.1s - 496.7s]: That's so beautiful.

[498.2s - 505.6s]: So love, interesting segue to get into talking about some of these other issues affecting our health,

[505.7s - 511.2s]: like genetically modified organisms, pesticides, glyphosate.

[511.5s - 517.0s]: Can you explain for our audience what's going on with all of the food and agricultural

[517.7s - 520.0s]: practices and how is that impacting us?

[520.4s - 520.6s]: Sure.

[521.0s - 526.8s]: So the reason why companies genetically modify crops is so that they can widespread spray,

[527.4s - 531.9s]: pesticides and herbicides, especially to kill off the weed, but not the crop.

[532.5s - 539.3s]: So then they've also had to design a crop that can withstand that and not get killed by something

[539.3s - 540.4s]: that's designed to kill.

[541.3s - 541.4s]: Right.

[541.4s - 547.4s]: So they genetically modified, let's say, the corn, for example, to withstand glyphosate,

[547.8s - 552.7s]: for example, which is an herbicide, again, designed to kill the herbs,

[553.3s - 556.5s]: and, but that gets soaked up as well into the corn.

[556.6s - 560.8s]: So we're getting doses of herbicides and pesticides.

[561.6s - 566.0s]: And as you know, very well, limited soil nutrition.

[566.5s - 570.1s]: So the quality of our foods has gone down significantly.

[570.7s - 572.3s]: And the conventional world.

[573.1s - 578.4s]: And already, many of these poisons I understand have been banned in other countries.

[578.7s - 579.0s]: Absolutely.

[579.3s - 583.7s]: But here in the United States, like it or not, we're basically the unwitting

[584.5s - 586.9s]: lab rats in a great experiment right now.

[587.3s - 588.4s]: Yeah, it's really unfortunate.

[589.0s - 589.1s]: Yeah.

[589.6s - 591.6s]: I mean, when we're seeing it, it's obvious.

[591.8s - 597.4s]: By the cancer rate, the diabetes, the obesity, people are eating high density of calories

[597.4s - 599.6s]: with very low density of nutrition.

[600.0s - 603.0s]: And a high density of toxins and poisons.

[603.3s - 604.1s]: No wonder.

[604.5s - 606.2s]: Of course, there's cancer growing rates.

[607.0s - 607.3s]: Of course.

[607.7s - 609.3s]: How could we expect anything different?

[610.0s - 616.4s]: So what are some of the ways we can deal with that or avoid those kinds of toxins?

[616.7s - 619.3s]: I highly advocate buying organic.

[620.2s - 624.5s]: Local locally sourced, if you can buy from your farmer only, that's the best.

[624.5s - 628.0s]: Because they're picking the fruits and vegetables right off the tree.

[628.0s - 630.5s]: Usually the day before they're bringing it to market.

[630.6s - 633.5s]: So you're getting the most ripe fruits and veggies.

[635.0s - 636.0s]: And seasonal.

[636.2s - 639.6s]: Make sure you're buying seasonal because if something's not in season,

[639.8s - 642.2s]: that means it's probably being shipped from across the world.

[642.6s - 644.5s]: Again, it's being picked way before it's ripe.

[644.6s - 647.8s]: That means it hasn't absorbed all the nutrients it needs from the soils.

[649.4s - 652.0s]: And what I've heard, and I haven't verified this,

[652.0s - 657.8s]: but I understand that when fruits cross the border, they get sprayed against fruit flies.

[658.5s - 662.0s]: So even if it's organic, you're getting a pesticide layer.

[662.2s - 665.0s]: And you can feel that like an apple, for example, that's waxy.

[665.9s - 668.1s]: That's wax infused with pesticides.

[668.9s - 674.2s]: So very important to get local organic fresh ripe raw fruits and veggies.

[674.4s - 679.4s]: Don't cook your food as little as little as at all as possible because you want all those nutrients.

[679.4s - 683.4s]: There are some foods that some nutrients come out more so like in tomatoes,

[683.8s - 686.1s]: the lycopene comes out more when you cook it.

[687.0s - 691.7s]: And kale and broccoli becomes a little more absorbable digestible,

[692.3s - 693.5s]: lightly steams.

[693.5s - 696.7s]: Not this like heavy long-term cooking and high heat.

[696.9s - 697.8s]: It's destructive.

[698.0s - 702.3s]: You destroy the enzymes that help you break the food down and the nutrient quantities.

[704.0s - 708.5s]: And the other thing I highly advocated is moving towards a plant-based diet.

[708.5s - 715.3s]: And that is because the livestock production system that we have now is feeding these cows and pigs

[715.3s - 719.1s]: and chickens corn and soy that has been genetically modified.

[719.5s - 722.6s]: So again, that's boosted full of pesticides and herbicides.

[723.5s - 729.5s]: And the cows, the animals are pumped full of antibiotics to make them fatter quicker

[730.4s - 731.5s]: and growth hormones.

[732.2s - 737.8s]: So those things combined bioaccumulate in the meat and the milk of the animals.

[738.4s - 740.1s]: And then we consume them.

[740.6s - 743.4s]: And so it's very dangerous for our system.

[744.4s - 748.5s]: And of course the misery of these poor animals are being treated horrifically.

[748.6s - 752.7s]: And if you believe in energy, then you know that there's an energy transfer.

[753.2s - 755.6s]: And if something that's been suffering, it's entire life.

[756.3s - 760.7s]: I mean, baby calves are taken away from their moms at three days old and put in a pen that they

[760.7s - 763.8s]: can't even turn around for months. That's how they live.

[764.4s - 765.4s]: But baby wants to play.

[766.2s - 771.0s]: So if an animal is suffering, so that's why we're going to have the baby back ribs that drives you nuts.

[771.2s - 774.3s]: But if the animal is suffering, you're ingesting suffering.

[774.5s - 777.5s]: And so of course we have the higher rates of depression and anxiety.

[777.8s - 779.6s]: And it makes sense.

[779.9s - 781.5s]: It makes so much sense.

[781.6s - 783.7s]: And it is so sad.

[784.5s - 791.0s]: One of the things that strikes me with folks in our line of work who are increasingly

[792.9s - 797.7s]: voicing, acknowledging there's so much to be sad about and into allow ourselves to just

[797.7s - 799.1s]: feel that sadness.

[799.4s - 802.4s]: Regardless of what we're doing about it, because there's a lot to do,

[803.0s - 806.0s]: to just acknowledge how sad it is right now.

[806.3s - 811.2s]: With the way we're treating animals, the way we're treating each other, the way we're treating this planet.

[813.2s - 820.5s]: One of our recent guests, my friend Kevin Townley, who has a very interesting, religious and

[820.5s - 826.2s]: alchemical background, spiritual background, speaks to the life force, the prana.

[827.4s - 832.1s]: And I think Star Wars was on to way more than many of us perhaps recognize

[833.4s - 835.0s]: when talking about the force.

[835.7s - 839.6s]: Interestingly, a lot of those incredible worlds that were filmed were real places,

[839.8s - 843.7s]: right? Like the snow planet that was Scandinavia, right?

[844.4s - 847.8s]: Like the Endor Ewa planet that was Northern California.

[847.8s - 849.1s]: I mean, it's just on and on.

[849.7s - 854.2s]: But this life force thing is so important and you're speaking to it in terms of the freshness

[854.2s - 858.4s]: of the local fruits and vegetables we get from local farmers.

[858.6s - 864.0s]: There's a whole different caliber of energy, vivifying energy in that food.

[864.2s - 870.3s]: And frankly, our science coupled with profit motives this last century has totally lost

[870.3s - 871.6s]: sight of this reality.

[872.2s - 877.7s]: And I think one of the opportunities we have is to re-engage with food on the basis of

[877.7s - 880.3s]: the life force that is animating all of us.

[880.5s - 881.0s]: Yeah, it's true.

[881.3s - 885.0s]: Remember the scientists, I forget his name, did the experiment water?

[886.0s - 888.3s]: And he put love and beautiful words on one.

[888.8s - 888.8s]: 

[889.2s - 890.9s]: And unkind words on the other.

[891.3s - 895.6s]: And you could see the different crystallizations, the forms, and one was beautiful.

[896.0s - 897.0s]: But the same, it's energy.

[897.3s - 899.0s]: It's energy into the water, it's energy into the food.

[899.6s - 900.0s]: Absolutely.

[900.7s - 900.8s]: Yeah.

[901.0s - 901.0s]: 

[901.2s - 902.2s]: Yeah, and water, right?

[902.6s - 905.4s]: Molecularly is essentially a liquid crystal,

[905.4s - 909.7s]: a set of liquid crystals, and it has memory, right?

[910.1s - 913.2s]: It conveys experience over time.

[913.8s - 918.6s]: And of course, our bodies are made up of what, around three-quarters water or something like that.

[918.6s - 918.7s]: Right.

[919.3s - 919.4s]: Yeah.

[919.6s - 920.0s]: Amazing.

[920.4s - 921.1s]: Yeah, that's true.

[921.4s - 926.1s]: You've mentioned the importance of paying attention to the water we're drinking

[926.1s - 928.1s]: and the other beverages we're drinking.

[928.3s - 931.0s]: Can you explain to our audience what you're talking about there?

[931.1s - 932.2s]: Yes, so important.

[932.2s - 935.0s]: The EWG, Environmental Working Group.

[935.3s - 939.5s]: You can go on their website and they have a section where you can put your zip code in

[939.5s - 940.5s]: to their website.

[941.0s - 946.0s]: And it will tell you the contaminants that are found in your resource, in your reservoir.

[947.7s - 948.8s]: And fascinating.

[949.6s - 951.5s]: Most places tout their water,

[952.2s - 953.0s]: Aspen especially.

[953.5s - 958.1s]: And if you put Aspen zip code, I found four cancer-causing chemicals in our water.

[958.7s - 960.2s]: That's what the EWG says.

[961.1s - 965.8s]: And this used to be a mining town, so that potentially might be the source.

[966.1s - 969.4s]: Or maybe it's the cleaning agents that they're using.

[969.6s - 974.2s]: I don't know the origins, but it's a fascinating thing to look into.

[975.0s - 977.9s]: So I highly advocate filtering your water.

[978.6s - 980.9s]: If you can do your whole house, that's phenomenal.

[981.2s - 982.4s]: If you can just do under your sink.

[983.0s - 985.2s]: Or I love the new burky system.

[985.5s - 986.8s]: I have it's a two-little container.

[986.8s - 990.1s]: I put right on top of the sink and it makes me a gallon and a half of water in five minutes.

[990.5s - 991.3s]: It's fabulous.

[992.0s - 994.0s]: And you can taste the difference and definitely feel it.

[994.7s - 996.2s]: That's so beautiful.

[996.7s - 999.8s]: And it seems like water, it's so fundamental, right?

[1000.6s - 1006.2s]: The more we can ensure our water is coming into our bodies in a clean form,

[1007.1s - 1012.1s]: probably will mean also we're going to be less likely to buy those sodas and those other

[1012.1s - 1014.7s]: manufactured consumer packaged drinks.

[1015.1s - 1017.2s]: Because who knows what's in that water, right?

[1017.4s - 1018.3s]: Right, that's so true.

[1018.8s - 1021.5s]: Yeah, and the acidity level is an issue for people's bodies.

[1021.9s - 1022.3s]: Absolutely.

[1022.6s - 1025.2s]: Having a more alkaline water is so important.

[1025.5s - 1025.6s]: Yeah.

[1026.0s - 1026.2s]: Yeah.

[1026.9s - 1026.9s]: 

[1027.4s - 1031.7s]: Well, I want to make sure to remind our audience that this is the

[1031.7s - 1035.8s]: Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.

[1036.3s - 1038.9s]: We're talking with Dr. Nicholas Ciso.

[1039.5s - 1042.7s]: And I want to be sure to thank our sponsors.

[1043.4s - 1047.6s]: This includes the Association of Walder Schools of North America,

[1048.0s - 1055.1s]: Purium, Equal Exchange, the International Society of Sustainability Professionals,

[1055.8s - 1060.8s]: Patagonia, Waylay Waters, Earth Coast Productions.

[1061.6s - 1067.1s]: And that group is helping to make possible an amazing three day curated summit

[1067.1s - 1069.7s]: that we're hosting outside Boulder, Colorado.

[1070.2s - 1078.6s]: This May 17 to 19, called massively mobilizing sustainability, deep leadership for the 21st

[1078.6s - 1081.0s]: century. And we have a very special offer.

[1081.2s - 1090.0s]: You can get a 25% discount on your VIP all-access ticket for the summit using the code Dr. Nicola.

[1090.0s - 1093.1s]: So it's DR-NI-C-O-L-A.

[1094.3s - 1098.4s]: And we're so excited to share that with the audience and celebration of this episode.

[1099.3s - 1104.5s]: And we're going to be diving even deeper on many of these topics and identifying actually some

[1104.5s - 1109.7s]: of the biggest business opportunities for impact entrepreneurs and executives

[1110.6s - 1119.0s]: to help us over these coming years and decades create a much cleaner, safer, and more compassion-based

[1119.7s - 1127.2s]: world economy. So I want to ask you, we've been talking about the the health side of this

[1128.0s - 1132.9s]: and you also studied sustainability and environmental management at Harvard.

[1133.2s - 1138.8s]: And I'm really curious what dots have you connected there or what what were you diving into

[1138.8s - 1144.2s]: while working on that degree that is now playing into your work helping folks become more healthy?

[1144.2s - 1149.4s]: Yeah, you know, one interesting study that I came across while I was there was that

[1150.0s - 1158.0s]: if the whole world were to shift to plant-based for one day a week, just one day a week,

[1158.1s - 1164.5s]: we would have vert the trends of global warming. And that was based on the fact that animal production,

[1165.1s - 1169.1s]: livestock production causes more environmental emissions.

[1170.6s - 1172.7s]: Yeah, greenhouse gas emissions.

[1172.7s - 1174.4s]: The greenhouse gas emissions.

[1174.5s - 1176.6s]: The greenhouse gas emissions then all of transportation combined.

[1177.7s - 1182.6s]: And so that just that minor shift amid their companies have come up with meatless Monday now,

[1182.8s - 1190.1s]: there's been some campaigns. But that minor shift in that in the lower demand of animal production.

[1190.3s - 1198.0s]: And the reason is it's not only because the animals excrete methane from both ends,

[1199.1s - 1208.1s]: they also, the crops used to feed them is incredibly industrial demanding,

[1208.7s - 1215.6s]: to ship, to store, to produce itself. Of course, the pesticides again running off into the waters,

[1216.0s - 1218.3s]: destroying our ecosystems, going into the oceans.

segments.text: Welcome to the Y on Earth communities stewardship and sustainability podcast series.
Today I have the great privilege of visiting with Dr. Nikola Siso.
Hi Nikola.
Hello, thank you for having me on your podcast.
It's so great to have you on the show and it's such a funny situation here because we're
actually in your studio setup for your show.
That's right.
I'm the founder of Aspen Talks Health where we discuss all sorts of health related topics,
nutrition, exercise, diet, brain health, gut health, environmental toxins.
So you were quite a compliment to my show today.
Thank you.
This is so much fun.
We get to basically interview each other in converse situations.
We even changed chairs for the occasion.
Didn't we?
Yes.
So Dr. Nikola Siso is a PhD in holistic health and nutrition.
She is also a certified holistic health coach.
And as she mentioned, she's the founder of Aspen Talks Health where she interviews experts
in every aspect of health and healing.
And she has a master's in sustainability and environmental management from Harvard University.
And so before we dive into a number of the topical areas where your expert related to our
personal health, I want to ask you, Nikola, how did you get into all of this in the first place?
Health has always been a ventious to me.
Since I was 15 years old, I loved diving into the spirituality and the emotional components
of health.
And then the nutrition as well, my mother studied at the Hippocrates Health Institute 20 years
ago.
And so we've learned how to be on a plant-based diet healthfully because there's ways
to do it unhealthy.
And then I actually ended up developing type 1 diabetes despite all of that.
And so that led me even further into understanding what are some of the root causes because it's
not just genetic and it's certainly not just sugar, high fat diets, antibiotic use, adverse
childhood experiences, mold exposure.
I mean, I'm learning so much as to the causes of health decline that it's never just one
thing.
So the show came about just because I'm personally interested.
And I do it anyway for joy every day is learning from experts in all these different fields.
So why not share what I'm learning with the community?
It's so powerful and such an incredible resource.
I want to just mention really quickly since we're on the topic, folks can find this resource
at aspenetalkshealth.com.
You're also on YouTube at a channel which will make sure is in the show notes and your
Facebook is Aspen Talks Health as well.
So I want to make sure folks that you get to this resource and see not only the expertise
that Dr. Ciso is bringing to the public but also that her guests on the show are bringing
to the public as well.
And I have to ask you because I also have this wonderful privilege of interviewing a variety
of experts.
What's been the most unusual or surprising insight or guest that you've had on the show?
I would say Dr. Rudy Tanzi, he is a professor of neurology at Harvard Medical School,
discovered the genes that cause Alzheimer's and he said that they did a whole study on how
to prevent Alzheimer's and one of the list was being more loving.
And I found that so beautiful because so much of our, we think so much of the health is
just related to nutrition and environmental toxins for example which a good majority is
but also how are we treating ourselves and how loving are we being to other people in our lives.
It was a beautiful thing that actually prevented Alzheimer's.
That is extraordinary.
Yeah.
I love hearing that.
Thank you.
So one of the things that strikes me you know I have the opportunity to connect with folks from
a variety of backgrounds.
Some who might be really faith oriented in their connection with the world.
Some who might be science oriented, STEM oriented, others who might be focused more on economy
and so forth.
And one of the things I have found that a lot of my friends who focus on the science lens
is we can often fall into the trap of seeing all this kind of reduced mechanism, mechanical
phenomena as dictating things like health or things like sustainability and what have you
and to have somebody from the medical community emphasizing the importance of love
is tremendous, right?
It is beautiful.
Of course love has been central to so much of our human wisdom and teachings over the ages
from all different cultures.
Yeah, it's so true.
We just, we don't think we're conscious all the time of the inner dialogue.
So much of it is subconscious.
And it's ruling our lives.
And it's attracting things into our lives and it's certainly manifesting as physical ailments
if there are so many sabotaging beliefs in there.
Yeah.
So for you personally with all of the technical knowledge you have, what are some of the
things you're doing day to day week to week to cultivate that love, whether it's self-lover,
love directed toward others?
One thing is certainly doing a meditation practice in the morning, having that, even if it's
just three minutes of breathing, it's so key.
And I just, I keep it simple.
I count inhale one, exhale two, inhale three, exhale four, and I go to six and I start
over.
And the reason that's to keep it short is it keeps your mind focused on the inhale and
it, but inhaling and exhaling.
The other thing is to look in the mirror and say, I love you, I love you and see the parts
that you love about yourself instead of focusing on the parts that you don't.
That has been a big transformer for me.
And also one of the biggest, most powerful lessons I've learned this past year was that
every single experience and every person that comes into my life be a positive or negative
is in direct service to my soul.
And if I could see everything, how is this serving me?
And even if it's negative and you're like, that person is a full in the blank and they're
just behaving unkindly, how can I actually use this as a way to practice kindness or practice
compassion?
You know, who knows what they're going through or how they're erased or whatever it was?
So seeing every single experience as an opportunity to be more loving.
It's absolutely beautiful.
Yeah.
I have to mention, this reminds me of my, my mother is so good at sometimes reminding me.
And you know, when we're doing this kind of work, when we're reaching out, sharing with the
public, interfacing networking, scheduling, invariably we can run into some friction here and there,
right?
And my mother reminds me often that if somebody is coming at us with, you know, kind of cold,
prickly feelings or whatever, that is almost certainly about something going on in their lives
and has virtually nothing to do with me or us necessarily.
Right.
And to learn not to take that kind of stuff quite as personally and certainly not to then amplify
it or redirect it, right?
I think that's one of the things that can often happen when we're having these negative experiences.
Yeah, there's a projection of their own inner unhappiness or dissatisfaction with themselves often
or, yeah, and you can't, to take things personally is really pointless.
Unless it's constructive criticism from a friend and there's like something that you can
learn from, that's different.
Yeah.
But if it's just a projection, then, yeah, you have to just honor the person where they are.
Mm-hmm.
That's so beautiful.
So love, interesting segue to get into talking about some of these other issues affecting our health,

pesticides and herbicides, especially to kill off the weed, but not the crop.
So then they've also had to design a crop that can withstand that and not get killed by something
that's designed to kill.

So they genetically modified, let's say, the corn, for example, to withstand glyphosate,
for example, which is an herbicide, again, designed to kill the herbs,

So we're getting doses of herbicides and pesticides.

And the conventional world.

Absolutely.

Yeah, it's really unfortunate.
Yeah.
I mean, when we're seeing it, it's obvious.

And a high density of toxins and poisons.
No wonder.
Of course, there's cancer growing rates.
Of course.
How could we expect anything different?
So what are some of the ways we can deal with that or avoid those kinds of toxins?
I highly advocate buying organic.
Local locally sourced, if you can buy from your farmer only, that's the best.
Because they're picking the fruits and vegetables right off the tree.
Usually the day before they're bringing it to market.
So you're getting the most ripe fruits and veggies.
And seasonal.
Make sure you're buying seasonal because if something's not in season,
that means it's probably being shipped from across the world.
Again, it's being picked way before it's ripe.
That means it hasn't absorbed all the nutrients it needs from the soils.
And what I've heard, and I haven't verified this,
but I understand that when fruits cross the border, they get sprayed against fruit flies.
So even if it's organic, you're getting a pesticide layer.
And you can feel that like an apple, for example, that's waxy.
That's wax infused with pesticides.
So very important to get local organic fresh ripe raw fruits and veggies.
Don't cook your food as little as little as at all as possible because you want all those nutrients.
There are some foods that some nutrients come out more so like in tomatoes,
the lycopene comes out more when you cook it.
And kale and broccoli becomes a little more absorbable digestible,
lightly steams.
Not this like heavy long-term cooking and high heat.
It's destructive.
You destroy the enzymes that help you break the food down and the nutrient quantities.
And the other thing I highly advocated is moving towards a plant-based diet.
And that is because the livestock production system that we have now is feeding these cows and pigs
and chickens corn and soy that has been genetically modified.
So again, that's boosted full of pesticides and herbicides.
And the cows, the animals are pumped full of antibiotics to make them fatter quicker
and growth hormones.
So those things combined bioaccumulate in the meat and the milk of the animals.
And then we consume them.
And so it's very dangerous for our system.
And of course the misery of these poor animals are being treated horrifically.

And if something that's been suffering, it's entire life.
I mean, baby calves are taken away from their moms at three days old and put in a pen that they

So if an animal is suffering, so that's why we're going to have the baby back ribs that drives you nuts.

And so of course we have the higher rates of depression and anxiety.

It makes so much sense.
And it is so sad.
